div.head: Section 3
div.p: ยง. 3

Proposition 2: Not only does this good of honor and good opinion among posterity accrue to the dead, which is in a certain way to live perpetually and always, as has been said, but it also greatly matters to the living who were joined to the deceased either by blood or affinity or even friendship.

The proposition is proved:
Just as the nobility of parents which they acquired through virtues, riches, knowledge, industry, eloquence, military affairs, administration of the republic, or greater dignity or any other uncommon excellence descends as if by propagation to posterity, so that they follow the condition of their ancestors. As is excellently proved in
l. 1 where Bartholus
and
Johannes de Platea
and in l. si senator and in
l. mulieres, Codex on dignities, book 12
and in
l. senatoris filium, Digest on the senate
and from that nobility and virtues by which predecessors attained it, posterity and descendants glory and often boast themselves vigorously. So if their ancestors were marked by some disgrace or infamy of morals especially, or some injury is inflicted upon them, without doubt all descendants are struck by the confusion of the same reproach, and the honor of all of them is detracted from. For if some honor is shown to parents already dead, such as when their memory is praised and celebrated, it is manifest that such honor redounds to sons and grandsons and great-grandsons and to all descendants. On the contrary, however, if some dishonors were done to them, for example if they were exhumed or their bones were burned, great injury would be inflicted on the living and sons and other descendants and relatives. Similarly indeed there redound to deceased parents the good or evil which come to sons, grandsons, great-grandsons and other posterity of theirs, namely both prosperities and dishonors, infamies or misfortunes, that is good and bad operations from which honors or dishonors proceed. For he is more illustrious who leaves excellent successors than he who leaves none or bad ones, thus
the Philosopher
argues and concludes in Ethics 1.

All these things are clear from that passage of
Ecclesiasticus chapter 3 :
Do not glory in the dishonor of your father, for it is not glory to you but confusion, for the glory of man is from the honor of his father, and a father without honor is the disgrace of the son . And chapter 41:
Be ashamed before father and mother of fornication . And a little below:
Of an impious father the sons complain because through him they are in reproach . Whence injury is inflicted on sons from the fornicating birth of their mother, as in
Authenticum on restitutions and that which gives birth, final paragraph of the collation . Likewise it is disgraceful to a father if a son takes a dishonorable wife,
Digest on contracting purchase, law 3 .

It is relevant to the proposition what Valerius relates in book 3 chapter 5 or according to another volume chapter 305 concerning Aeneas Scipio, son of Scipio Africanus the Elder, who was like a monster considering the glory and virtues of his father, from which he himself had greatly degenerated, and on account of the stains of his shameful vices among other ignominies inflicted upon him, when the honor of the praetorship had been conferred upon him by the Roman people or by a certain scribe of his father to whom the Roman people had granted it, his relatives and kinsmen, considering that he was going to pollute that dignity on account of his vices and shamefulness and that the reproach and disgrace of him would redound to all of them, so terrified him that he did not dare to place the praetorian seat or to pronounce judgment among litigants. And moreover they took from his hand the ring in which the head of Africanus the Elder was sculpted. And Valerius adds:
Good gods, what darkness from what lightning did you suffer to be born, that is, what obscurations of the brightness of name and fame did you suffer to be born.

It is clear therefore that all relatives and those who are of the same genealogy or kinship are damaged by the reproach or ignominy of any one of them. From this it is that one who offends someone or some people in person or in goods is said to offend not only them but also whoever is from the kinship of the offended. This is proved by
the chapter "olim" on injuries and damage done , where an injury inflicted on a bishop seems to be inflicted on all subject churches because he is the spouse of those churches. Whence inferior churches can act for an injury inflicted upon them, as there.
And on account of this, power of vengeance is sometimes given to the same kinsmen, as in
l. raptores, Codex on sacrosanct churches , where it is said that the power of killing by their own authority is given to the kinsmen of virgins and women dedicated to God who have been raped. And from these things
the gloss on l. lex cornelia, Digest on injuries : because an injury inflicted on one of the kinship seems done to the whole kinship. This is also clear in Genesis 14 from the deed of Abraham who avenged the plunder committed against Lot his nephew when he went against four kings, and Simeon and Levi against the rapists of Dinah their sister having been killed.

The reason for the aforesaid things is that the whole kinship makes one body, of which the individual parts or members make individuals of that kinship, as in
l. cum scimus, Codex on farmers and those registered, book 11 . For we are one with our parents,
on penance, distinction 4, chapter "What is said" . For father and son are reckoned as one head and as one person, as in
l. fine, Digest on minors and substitutions , where it is said:
Since from nature father and son are understood to be almost the same person, they are one flesh ,
question 35.3, paragraph "by this authority" . Likewise a son is part of his father, as
the Philosopher says in Ethics 5 :
for he is his blood ,
Digest on undutiful testament, law "non enim"
and
the voice of the father is as the voice of the son, Institutes on useless stipulations, paragraph "ei qui" , and the heir is considered one person with the deceased in the Authenticum on oath sworn by one dying at the beginning, namely for that part by which he is heir, note
Digest on praetorian stipulations, law 2, in the last gloss . Indeed the nature of the father walks in the person of the son, and the memory of parents is conserved in children and through children in the same way,
Digest on the signification of words, law "mulier," paragraph "cum proportionaretur" . And by the appellation of parent not only father but also grandfather and great-grandfather and thenceforth all superiors to infinity are contained, but also mother and grandmother and great-grandmother,
Digest on the signification of words, law "appellatione"
and
Digest on summoning to court, law 4, paragraph "praetor"
and
paragraph "parentes" . Similarly by the appellation of children, grandsons and great-grandsons a nd all who descend from the same stock and are born are comprehended and make a kinship, as in
law "liberorum," Digest on the signification of words . They also make a family, house and people, that is consanguinity, as is proved in
law "pronuntiato," paragraph "familie," element 2
and
paragraph "communi iure," Digest in that title .

Since therefore the whole one kinship, family, house and people, that is consanguinity, makes one mystical or imagined body,
and individually they are members of one another , as
the Apostle says to the Romans 12 , and by natural inclination
the members are solicitous for each other in the same thing, and if one member suffers, all members suffer together; but if one member is glorified, all members rejoice together , as also
the Apostle says in 1 Corinthians 12 . Therefore if a father or superior or any of the ascendants of any family, house or people or kinship and consanguinity, or a son or grandson or great-grandson or any of the descendants or even collateral relatives acts or suffers some injury or reproach or disgrace or something shameful, injurious or dishonorable, similarly on account of the illustrious deeds of any of them or glory and honor attained on account of merits, it redounds to the whole family or kinship etc.

Therefore not only does any good of honor or happy opinion among posterity accrue to the dead (which is in a certain way to live perpetually), but it also matters to the living who were joined to the deceased either by blood, family, kinship, affinity or even friendship, because from such honor or honoring, glory or disgrace of the dead they themselves receive advantage or disadvantage. And thus the second proposition is clear.

The third proposition which follows from the preceding ones: To store great treasures or riches with the bodies of the deceased is a manifest argument that neither the dead who ordered them to be buried with themselves nor the living successors who permit them to remain in the tombs of their ancestors placed them there with that intention
or allow them to be there so that they would have them or have them as abandoned things, or renounced tacitly or expressly the right and ownership which they had in them. And consequently that the aforesaid treasures and riches have an owner and are another's property.

The proposition is proved first from the first proposition, because the intention and mind of the dead and living who ordered them to be buried with themselves and who permit them to remain in the tombs is so that from this they may obtain honor, glory, and praise among posterity and so that their glorious status, wealth, and magnificence may become known to future ages, and so they may live perpetually in the opinions of men. And this is a great interest to them. Therefore neither the living nor the dead had the intention to leave the riches and treasures aforesaid as abandoned things.

Secondly, it is proved by a sign thus: When things which are found and whose owner is not known are precious and of great value, it is a sign that they are not held or were held as abandoned things wherever they are found. Whence they ought not be thought to lack an owner or owners, dead or living, since no one throws away such things from themselves, but either possesses and preserves them or gives them away. But the treasures and riches and those things which were stored in the aforesaid tombs with kings and nobles were most precious things. Therefore it is a sign that they were not held as abandoned things. For it is not likely that such precious things would be so disdained.

Thirdly, it is proved from the places in which they are found. For they are found in tombs or in temples of their gods, and they guarded the doors with locks and bars lest they be taken by thieves, as was said in the beginning. Therefore it is a sign that they did not hold them as abandoned things.

Fourthly, it is proved from a similar case: for if someone finds in the sea or on the seashore something which was cast out from a ship for the sake of lightening the ship, on account of the place in which it is found no one ought to presume or think that it is held as abandoned, but rather not the contrary. Since those things which are cast into the sea for the sake of lightening the ship are not held as abandoned things, because they are not cast with that mind that they not be possessed further or that the owners lose or throw away their ownership of them, but because the possessing owner wishes to save his life which is more precious to him than riches. Whence it is clear that to find things in the sea or on the seashore is a sign that the owner of them did not hold them as abandoned things; things, I say, which are not accustomed to be on the seashore except very rarely and by chance on account of them;
I say namely little stones or gems which are born there which are in no one's goods and therefore become the finder's. These things are proved in
the Institutes on the division of things, final paragraph
and
Digest on thefts, law "falsus," paragraph "si iactum"
and
Digest on threatened damage, law "si finita," paragraph "si quis metu" .

In this way it must be said that if someone was carrying great burdens on the road and could not carry further and left them, or if fleeing enemies he could not carry his things and therefore leaves them on the road, although he thinks that he will not find them when he returns or that perhaps he will never have them, he will not be said to hold them as abandoned things.

These therefore are manifest signs which make a vehement presumption by reason of place that things which are found are not held as abandoned things nor do they lack an owner, and thus they are another's property.

Thus therefore it is concerning treasures and other precious things which are found in tombs or in temples of their gods, because certainly they were not placed there so that they would be held as abandoned things, but so that they would be best preserved there perpetually and from this would bring honor, praise, and good opinion to the owners now deceased and their living descendants. On this see
Hostiensis in his Summa, title on the cause of property, paragraph "what property is," at the word "Likewise through tradition."

And the aforesaid things are confirmed by an example which we both understand and see manifestly among us. Let us ask, I say, whether kings and magnates and noble and Catholic men have held as abandoned those precious things, namely those standards or insignia or shields of gold and silver, tombs covered with cloths of silk and woven with gold which the deceased fathers and their ancestors placed in the chapels of churches where they were buried. And whether the dead and the surviving living descendants of them would be offended if someone should try to take those things either by theft or violently. For it is manifest that not only the dead and the living, but also the whole kinship, house, and family would be offended and would take it as injuries.

Fifthly, the proposition is proved because those precious things which were stored with the bodies of the deceased in tombs are not properly treasures, which are in the goods of no one which are acquired entirely by the finder if he finds them in his own ground. For that is properly a treasure to which the definition of treasure applies, which is placed in
law "unica," Codex on treasures, book 10 :
a treasure is money hidden from unknown owners in more ancient time, of which disposition no memory exists, as there and
Institutes on the division of things, paragraph "thesauros" . From unknown owners, that is, money was hidden by some men who never recovered it, and it remained there for the longest time, so much so that now through forgetfulness it has gone out from the possession and ownership of humans according to
Johannes de Platea on said law "unica" .

But improperly a treasure is said, according to the same author, when memory exists, as when someone hid it for the sake of profit or fear or custody, add also of honor or some other good consideration. And nothing is owed to the finder from this, rather he commits theft, but it belongs to him who hid it or to his heirs, as is the text in
law "nunquam," paragraph "thesaurus," Digest on acquiring ownership of things at the end
and
law "thesaurus," Digest on exhibition
and
law "item habeo," Digest on dividing the estate
and
law "a tutore," Digest on rescinding a sale .

Since therefore those precious things were placed in tombs for the sake of custody and honor, praise, and glory of the living and deceased and of the whole kinship of kings and other great men, ascendants and descendants, of whom memory exists through succession, namely of king Inca or successors of the kings of those kingdoms, and so in other kingdoms of that world, therefore they are not treasures properly but improperly, and consequently they are not owed to finders. The conclusion is clear because they have not gone out from the possession and ownership of those people, and thus they have owners. And thus concerning the third proposition.
